ygData.subject: Re: Patents and suchlike...
ygData.msgSnippet: I can understand why you wouldn t want something like rtNEAT patented but let me try to explain a bit.  First, original NEAT is not patented and is in the

I can understand why you wouldn't want something like rtNEAT 
patented but let me try to explain a bit.  First, original NEAT is 
not patented and is in the public domain.  That is not an accident 
of timing, but rather intentional; I always wanted all my work in 
the public domain.  So let me explain what happened.

First, the good news is that there is no need for concern about 
sharing on this group, since sharing anything immediately makes it 
impossible for anyone to patent.  You can't patent something that 
has been publicly disclosed.  That means that it would be illegal 
for anyone here to patent anything that anyone else posted, and 
there is a record to prove it.  If you personally did want to patent 
your own stuff, just like anyone else who gets a patent, you'd need 
to first disclose it to the patent office, so they'd have a record 
of when you had your idea, which is called a "provisional patent."  
Then you'd be protected in the sense that the date is established 
and you could start sharing your idea.  If you have no ambitions to 
patent something, then you have nothing to fear about other people 
patenting your ideas if they were disclosed publicly.  The concern 
you bring up generally comes about only in private disclosures, e.g. 
I verbally tell my friend my idea and he goes and patents it.  Then 
there is no record of the disclosure so I can't prove that I in fact 
supplied the idea.  This group as a public forum (meaning there is a 
record kept) precludes that from happening. So no one can go steal a 
patent from you or anyone who participates here.

The real-time enhancement of NEAT, which is called rtNEAT, is the 
only thing that's patented.  If something in your design looks like 
rtNEAT in that it uses the same methodology in its continuous 
aspect, that aspect of it (and only that aspect) may be covered by 
the patent.   That is obviously a complicated legal question, in the 
sense that "looks like" is a legal opinion.  However, other details 
of your algorithm, such as the genetic representation, would not be 
covered.  Presumably there is nothing about the genetic code that 
requires a continuous formatted algorithm in the style of rtNEAT.  
So those things are separable, legally.  

So why is the real-time enhancement of NEAT patented?  It happened 
because of NERO.  I had no intention of patenting anything, as 
usual, when I created rtNEAT for NERO.  But what happened was a lot 
of companies started visiting our lab and expressing interest in 
rtNEAT after seeing early demos of NERO.  It became clear to me 
quickly that several parties (I won't go into specifics) were going 
to make a concerted effort to make money off of rtNEAT.  I am not 
saying anything bad about these parties; it's only natural they 
would want to do that.  But as the inventor, I can assure you, if 
you see that a bunch of people are going to try to go off and make 
money off of your ideas and you are going to get nothing for it, you 
will move to protect yourself.  So I was essentially forced to 
initiate the patent process.  It is even likely that if I didn't do 
it, someone else would have, because the people who own IP created 
at a University is the *University* and not me.  That is still true 
even if I initiate the process: The University of Texas at Austin 
owns the rights to the patent, not me.  However, by getting involved 
in it early, I established that I at least *deserve* to participate 
in any enterprise that results down the road.  As I said, I would 
not have been surprised if they patented it without me, because UT 
recognized they had something that could make money on their hands.

I'll tell you why I felt so strognly to protect myself.  rtNEAT was 
the result of years and years of my life's research, certainly not a 
small idea from a post.  It goes back to my early work on real-time 
evolution in 1997, running through NEAT, and finally enhancing NEAT 
to combine it with my earlier ideas.  I had always planned to 
combine NEAT with those ideas in the future, and the thoughts on how 
had been materializing for years.  It was a huge struggle to get 
into a position where I could actually create a game that would 
merit finally creating the technology, and a further struggle to 
promote the game in Texas and around the world, generating interest. 
Thus, after years of my life culminating in a situation where 
suddenly people were circling around the results of so much labor, 
there was little choice but to move to protect my involvement with 
the IP.  It is difficult to convey how it feels when years of hard 
work are about to be captilized on without you.  It was the only 
common sense choice to protect yourself.  

In any case, even though rtNEAT is patent-pending, it is still free 
to use for research purposes and will always be.  That's the policy 
of any university.  So it should not hamper people's desire to 
explore the idea.  And the most important point is, no one can 
patent anything you post here.  That would be illegal, and there is 
an easy way to prove that they ripped you off, so anyone who tried 
something like that would be foolish.   The free flow of ideas on 
this group therefore is not and should not be hampered.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> 
> >Another thing, which should not affect anyone, but is worth 
pointing
> >out, is that rtNEAT is patent pending and the patent is held by 
UT-
> >Austin.  That means if you wanted to make money off of it, you'd
> >have to talk to them to get a license.  Of course research doesn't
> >require any permission, so this shouldnt matter to most people.  
But
> >it's something to consider if you have greater ambitions.
> 
> Hi,
> 
> Obviously if anybody should patent parts of NEAT, it should be Ken.
> 
> But I'm still not sure I feel happy about it....
> 
> Did you patent the original NEAT?  Presumably if you didn't, you 
> can't now because its well in the public domain?
> 
> Hopefully this patent covers only the very specific implementation 
> details of rtNEAT and could never impinge on anything so unrelated 
as 
> continuous SLEAT?
> 
> The reason this matters is, for example, I have always freely 
shared 
> all my ideas and insights with the group.  But would I want to do 
> that if there was any possibility of my ideas becoming somebody 
> else's intellectual property?  I hurry to say I'm not saying this 
has 
> happened, I don't recall making any suggestions about this exact 
> area. I'm just saying that given we have a community here, which 
to 
> some extent develops together, I'm not at all encouraged by the 
idea 
> of some areas of our work becoming the property of less than us 
all.
> 
>          [[In fact, since this whole group is accessibly to 
anybody 
> who chooses to subscribe, we are effectively putting everything we 
> say here into the public domain, and I'd hate to see that limiting 
> what people think they can say, also.]]
> 
> Ian (hoping not to have to put a licensing agreement into his 
emails).
> 
> 
> In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
> 
> 
>
